Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Microscale Gradient Generation Device for Creating the Cellular Types Observed Across the Bone-Cartilage Interface
Award.AbstractNarration:
Articular cartilage is soft tissue that covers the ends of long bones in human joints, such as the knee joint, and acts to mitigate stress and wear. Articular cartilage transitions into bone through the osteochondral interface. The breakdown of articular cartilage and the osteochondral interface results in osteoarthritis, a disease affecting approximately 27 million Americans according to the CDC. Articular cartilage shows poor healing properties due to its lack of blood flow. Tissue engineered implants offer a promising method for healing articular cartilage in that they can be customized to fit the specific shapes and sizes of defects in articular cartilage, but these implants must show similar structure to cartilage found in the body. The structure and composition of articular cartilage changes with depth and proximity to bone, and these changes are consistent with changes in chondrocyte phenotype (the general shape and size of cartilage cells). This study is directed at recreating these cellular changes by placing chondrocytes into a collagen gel to simulate the knee environment and then applying a gradient of chemical factors that cause the cells to act as they would at the osteochondral interface. This work is performed in collaboration with Dr. Xingyu Jiang of the Chinese National Center for NanoScience and Technology (NCNST), an expert in using small fluid-based devices to affect cellular phenotype.

The study will create a flow-less chemical concentration gradient that allows for intercell signaling in a collagen gel environment that is similar to the extracellular matrix of articular cartilage. This gradient will be created through the design and construction of a microfluidic device that relies on diffusion-based principles to apply different chemical compounds that have been shown to affect chondrocyte phenotypes, creating a cellular gradient in hypertrophy similar to what is observed at the osteochondral interface. This work will be used to inform the design of tissue engineered implants for articular cartilage repair.

This award under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Ministry of Science and Technology of China.

ProgramReference.Text: US CHINA COOP IN BASIC SCIENCE

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was directed at fabricating a device for creating a gradient of cell types for the production of the interface between cartilage and bone that is found in human joints. Such a cellular gradient could be used to produce tissue engineered implants for cartilage repair in patients suffering from osteoarthritis or other related diseases. This collaborative work was performed at the National Center for Nanoscience and Technology (NCNST) in Beijing, China. Researchers at NCNST have expertise in creating microscale devices for controlling cellular changes, specifcally using gradient-based techniques. For this project, the principle investigator (PI) traveled to Beijing for two months in order to learn nanofabrication and cell-seeding techniques from established researchers in this field. Prior to travel, the PI produced a relevant design for the device described above with the assistance of his collaborators at NCNST, based on previous literature. At NCNST, the PI learned and used nanofabrication techniques to iteratively design a device that was able to put cell-seeding gel medias into contact with surrounding fluids. The PI produced a number of devices in China and returned to the United States with these devices. This work will continue as a collaboration in the United States. In the future, the PI will test the cell-seeding capabilities of the device and analyze gradient generation. 


Last Modified: 03/02/2017
Modified by: Alexander Boys
